data.text:
Tourism hit in Himachal as Shimla-Kalka train services suspended

Following disruption in train services, stakeholders is the tourism industry expressed concerns over the impact of the suspension as a large number of tourists visit the region during the current period.

The Shimla-Kalka narrow gauge railway line was halted as a precautionary measure after a railway bridge was washed out during last year's monsoon season, officials confirmed on June 22. There is no narrow gauge service available beyond Taradevi an official was quoted as saying by PTI.

"Four out of seven trains have been suspended while two trains are running until Taradevi and one till Kandaghat," the official confirmed.

Following the disruption in train services, stakeholders is the tourism industry expressed concerns over the impact of the suspension as a large number of tourists visit the region during the current period.

Also read: Solan beats Shimla to emerge as most-popular tourist hotspot in Himachal

"The tourists are welcomed in Shimla and there is nothing to worry about as the distance between Shimla and Taradevi railway station is just 11 km. The station is located adjacent to the main road and we request the transport department to start buses from Taradevi for the convenience of the commuters," MK Seth, President of Shimla Hotel and Tourism Stakeholders Association told PTI.

He pointed out that the railway authorities should have acted proactively and made permanent arrangements as its nearly a year since the bridge had collapse. "We wonder what will happen during the upcoming monsoon season," he said, criticising authorities.

Also read: Himachal tourism takes a big step to attract more travellers: Check details here

Moreover, Seth highlighted that there was no communication from railway authorities regarding the timeline for resuming train services to Shimla.

Last year, heavy rains in July and August caused widespread disruption in train services, with significant damage to the rail tracks at multiple locations. A landslide in August resulted in the collapse of a 50-meter bridge near Summer Hill.

However, services resumed in October after repairs were completed on the affected stretches. The 96 km UNESCO world heritage Shimla-Kalka Railway track, renowned for its challenging hilly terrain and 102 tunnels (following the collapse of one tunnel four decades ago), continues to face operational challenges due to natural hazards like heavy rains and landslides.

Meanwhile, the Shimla Meteorological department said on June 22 that heat wave conditions have abated in the state following light to moderate rains and thunderstorms at several places in the past 24 hours. The department has predicted relief from heat for three to four days. The Maximum temperatures are likely to decrease and will remain normal or above normal for the next three-four days.
